step.context: \text{If }(x^2 + 1)\cdot (x^2+2) = A\cdot (x^2+3)\cdot (x^2+4) + P(x),\\ \text{then what is } A = ?.\text{Ignore P(x) for now.}
step.tex: \text{A could be anything, including a polynomial }\\ \text{- like }ax+b.
step.reason: (x^2 + 1)\cdot (x^2+2) = x^4 + 3x^2 + 2 \\ \text{ and } (x^2+3)\cdot (x^2+4) = x^4 + 7x^2 + 12.\text{ Now,} \\ \text{if }x^4 + 3x^2 + 2 = A\cdot (x^4 + 7x^2 + 12) + P(x) \\ \text{then on comparing coefficients of }x^4, A = 1.

step.context: \text{Which of the following is mathematically correct?}
step.reason: \text{When you set }t = x^2\text{ and convert }x^2 + a\rightarrow t + a\\ \text{you forget that }x^2 + a\text{ is a quadratic}\\ \text{polynomial and not a linear one. That makes}\\ \text{all the difference to how the partial sum looks.}

\begin{align} &\dfrac{(x^2+1)\cdot (x^2+2)}{(x^2+3)\cdot (x^2+4)} = 1 + \dfrac{Ax+B}{x^2+3} + \dfrac{Cx+D}{x^2+4} \\ &\implies\underbrace{x^4+3x^2+1}_{(x^2+1)\cdot(x^2+2)} = \underbrace{x^4+7x^2+12}_{(x^2+3)\cdot(x^2+4)} \\ &+ A\cdot (x^2+4) + B\cdot (x^2+3)\\ &= x^4 + (A+C)x^3 + (7+B+D)x^2 \\ &+ (4A+3C)x + (12+4B+3D) \end{align}\\ \text{On comparing coefficients, we get }\\ \begin{tabular}{cc} x^3 & A+C = 0 \\ x^2 & B+D+7 = 3 \\ x & 4A+3C = 0 \\ x^0 & 12+4B+3D = 2 \end{tabular}\\ \text{Solve to get values for A,B,C and D.}
\text{Note that both X and Y are of the form}\\ \int\dfrac{dy}{y^2 + a^2 } = \dfrac{1}{a}\tan^{-1}\dfrac{y}{a} + C.
